summary: This document is an email chain from June 2008 regarding the Jeffrey Epstein case. An Assistant U.S. Attorney forwards a message to Roy, indicating that the Deputy Attorney General has completed a review and determined federal prosecution is appropriate. Epstein is given a deadline to comply with a plea agreement, including pleading guilty, being sentenced, and surrendering to begin his prison sentence.

connections.description: The Assistant U.S. Attorney is communicating with Roy about the Epstein matter, returning a call and forwarding information.
Jeff Sloman contacted the Assistant U.S. Attorney and asked them to return Roy's call regarding Epstein.
The Assistant U.S. Attorney sent an email to Jay Lefkowitz informing him of the decision to prosecute Epstein federally.
The email regarding the prosecution decision is addressed to Jay Lefkowitz, strongly suggesting he is acting as legal counsel or representative for Jeffrey Epstein.
The Deputy Attorney General reviewed the Epstein matter and made the decision that federal prosecution was appropriate.

events.title: Deadline for Epstein to comply with plea agreement
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein is given until the close of business on June 30, 2008, to comply with the terms of an agreement with the United States, including entering a guilty plea, being sentenced, and surrendering to begin his prison sentence.

events.title: Decision to prosecute Epstein federally
events.description: The Deputy Attorney General completes his review and determines that federal prosecution of Jeffrey Epstein's case is appropriate.

events.title: Modification of agreement
events.description: A letter from the U.S. Attorney on December 19th modified the agreement between the United States and Jeffrey Epstein.

keyFacts: In June 2008, the Deputy Attorney General completed a review and determined that federal prosecution of Jeffrey Epstein was appropriate.
Epstein was given a deadline of June 30, 2008, to comply with a plea agreement, which required him to plead guilty, be sentenced, and surrender to begin his prison sentence.
The communication indicates an existing agreement between the United States and Epstein, which had been modified by a U.S. Attorney's letter in December of the prior year.
